questions.question_text_1:
An RGB image of size 227 × 227 × 3 is first converted to grayscale and then passed through a 2D Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) layer with the following parameters: 
– Kernel size: 3 × 3 – Stride: 1 – Padding: 1 – Number of filters: 16 
What will be the shape of the output feature map?
question_texts:
An RGB image of size 227 × 227 × 3 is first converted to grayscale and then passed through a 2D Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) layer with the following parameters: 
– Kernel size: 3 × 3 – Stride: 1 – Padding: 1 – Number of filters: 16 
What will be the shape of the output feature map?

questions.question_text_1: Consider a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) where the feature map after the convolutional and pooling layers has a shape of (8, 8, 64). This feature map is flattened and connected to a fully connected layer with 256 output neurons.  How many parameters (weights and biases) are in this fully connected layer?
question_texts: Consider a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) where the feature map after the convolutional and pooling layers has a shape of (8, 8, 64). This feature map is flattened and connected to a fully connected layer with 256 output neurons.  How many parameters (weights and biases) are in this fully connected layer?

questions.question_text_1: In self-supervised depth estimation, left-right consistency loss is often used to ensure that the depth maps from stereo images agree with each other. Which of the following code snippets correctly implements a left-right consistency loss by reconstructing the left depth map from the right depth map using disparity?

questions.question_text_1: In the Fast R-CNN object detection pipeline, which of the following steps is NOT part of the preprocessing process?
question_texts: In the Fast R-CNN object detection pipeline, which of the following steps is NOT part of the preprocessing process?

options.option_text: Resize the input image to a fixed size.
Extract region proposals using Selective Search.
Apply a Region Proposal Network (RPN) to generate region proposals.
Extract features from the entire image using a CNN backbone beforeclassifying region proposals.

questions.question_text_1: LAKDNet is designed to enhance feature extraction and knowledge distillation in deep neural networks. Which of the following best describes its core architectural improvement?
question_texts: LAKDNet is designed to enhance feature extraction and knowledge distillation in deep neural networks. Which of the following best describes its core architectural improvement?

options.option_text: It employs a Dual Attention Mechanism (Spatial and Channel Attention) toimprove feature aggregation.
It uses Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) to capture hierarchicaldependencies in spatial features.
It integrates Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) to enhance temporalfeature extraction.
It relies on Transformer-based self-attention to capture global contextualdependencies.

questions.question_text_1: SRGAN is a deep learning-based approach for image super-resolution that improves the perceptual quality of upscaled images. Which of the following best describes the role of the adversarial loss in SRGAN?
question_texts: SRGAN is a deep learning-based approach for image super-resolution that improves the perceptual quality of upscaled images. Which of the following best describes the role of the adversarial loss in SRGAN?

options.option_text: It minimizes the pixel-wise difference between the super-resolved and high-resolution images to ensure pixel accuracy.
It encourages the generator to produce high-resolution images that areperceptually similar to real images by fooling the discriminator.
It directly optimizes the Structural Similarity Index (SSIM) to improve textureand detail preservation.
It ensures that the generated high-resolution images have better Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR) compared to traditional interpolation methods.

questions.question_text_1: In VGGNet, which part of the architecture contributes the most to memory utilization during training, and which part contains the **highest number of parameters?
question_texts: In VGGNet, which part of the architecture contributes the most to memory utilization during training, and which part contains the **highest number of parameters?

options.option_text: The early convolutional layers have the highest memory utilization, while thefully connected layers** have the highest number of parameters.
The fully connected layers have the highest memory utilization, while theconvolutional layers have the highest number of parameters.
The deeper convolutional layers have the highest memory utilization, whilethe **pooling layers** have the highest number of parameters.
The batch normalization layers have the highest memory utilization, while theskip connections have the highest number of parameters.

questions.question_text_1: In deep convolutional neural networks, 1 x 1 convolutions play a significant role in optimizing computation and feature extraction. Which of the following statements correctly describe their role in modern CNN architectures?
question_texts: In deep convolutional neural networks, 1 x 1 convolutions play a significant role in optimizing computation and feature extraction. Which of the following statements correctly describe their role in modern CNN architectures?

options.option_text: 1 x 1 convolutions can be used to perform dimensionality reduction byreducing the number of channels before applying computationally expensive convolutions.
They introduce non-linearity into the network, even when used withoutactivation functions.
1 x 1 convolutions enable cross-channel interactions by linearly combiningfeature maps from different channels.
In ResNet architectures, 1 x 1 convolutions are used in bottleneck blocks tomatch the dimensions when applying skip connections.
When applied after a max pooling layer, 1 x 1 convolutions help recover lostspatial information by increasing the resolution of the feature maps.

questions.question_text_1: Estimating depth from a single image using a multiscale deep neural network presents several challenges. Which of the following correctly describe these challenges?
question_texts: Estimating depth from a single image using a multiscale deep neural network presents several challenges. Which of the following correctly describe these challenges?

options.option_text: Understanding global context and handling variations in scene geometry andtextureless regions.
Dealing with scale ambiguity and the lack of absolute depth reference inmonocular images.
Reducing computational complexity while matching points across two images.
Handling occlusions and depth discontinuities, especially at object boundaries.
Accurately aligning stereo image pairs and computing disparity for depthestimation.

questions.question_text_1: Monocular depth estimation using a multiscale deep neural network presents several challenges due to the lack of direct depth cues. Which of the following is a primary challenge specific to monocular depth estimation?
question_texts: Monocular depth estimation using a multiscale deep neural network presents several challenges due to the lack of direct depth cues. Which of the following is a primary challenge specific to monocular depth estimation?

options.option_text: Handling scale ambiguity and the absence of absolute depth reference insingle images.
Accurately computing depth by triangulating matching keypoints between twoimages.
Estimating depth consistently in textureless regions and under varyinglighting conditions.
Using LiDAR or structured light to obtain precise depth values instead ofpredicting them.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **"Deep Learning Practices"** exam, along with a **Mermaid knowledge graph** to visualize relationships.

---

---

### **Core Topics & Concepts**
#### **1. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)**
   - **Architectures**: AlexNet, VGGNet, ResNet, Inception, U-Net.
   - **Key Layers**:
     - Convolutional layers (kernel size, stride, padding, output shape calculation).
     - Pooling layers (MaxPool, AvgPool, **MinPool**).
     - Fully Connected (FC) layers (parameter count: `input_features × output_neurons + biases`).
   - **1×1 Convolutions**: Dimensionality reduction, cross-channel interactions, bottleneck blocks (ResNet).
   - **Feature Map Shape Calculation**:
     \[
     \text{Output Size} = \left\lfloor \frac{\text{Input Size} - \text{Kernel Size} + 2 \times \text{Padding}}{\text{Stride}} \right\rfloor + 1
     \]
   - **Parameter Count in FC Layers**:
     \[
     \text{Parameters} = (\text{Input Features}) \times (\text{Output Neurons}) + \text{Biases}
     \]

#### **2. Transfer Learning & Fine-Tuning**
   - **Modifying Pretrained Models** (e.g., AlexNet):
     - Freeze feature extraction layers.
     - Replace the last FC layer for custom classes:
       ```python
       model.classifier[6] = nn.Linear(in_features, num_classes)  # AlexNet
       ```
   - **Example**: Adapting AlexNet for 10 classes (Q2).

#### **3. Object Detection**
   - **Metrics**:
     - **Intersection over Union (IoU)**:
       \[
       \text{IoU} = \frac{\text{Area of Intersection}}{\text{Area of Union}} = \frac{A_{\text{inter}}}{A_{\text{GT}} + A_{\text{Pred}} - A_{\text{inter}}}
       \]
     - **Precision/Recall/F1-Score**:
       \[
       \text{Precision} = \frac{\text{TP}}{\text{TP} + \text{FP}}, \quad \text{Recall} = \frac{\text{TP}}{\text{TP} + \text{FN}}, \quad F1 = 2 \times \frac{\text{Precision} \times \text{Recall}}{\text{Precision} + \text{Recall}}
       \]
     - **Mean Absolute Error (MAE)** for bounding boxes (Q8):
       \[
       \text{MAE} = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} \frac{1}{4} \sum_{j=1}^{4} |GT_{ij} - P_{ij}|
       \]
   - **Pipelines**:
     - **Fast R-CNN**: Selective Search (not RPN) → ROI Pooling → Classification.
     - **RPN (Region Proposal Network)**: Used in Faster R-CNN (not Fast R-CNN).

#### **4. Depth Estimation**
   - **Monocular Depth Estimation Challenges** (Q20, Q21):
     - Scale ambiguity (no absolute depth reference).
     - Textureless regions, lighting variations.
     - Occlusions and depth discontinuities.
   - **Stereo Depth Estimation**:
     - Left-right consistency loss (Q6):
       ```python
       depth_reconstructed = F.grid_sample(depth_right, disparity_left)
       loss = torch.mean((depth_left - depth_reconstructed)**2)
       ```
   - **Multiscale Networks**: Capture global context and fine details.

#### **5. Generative Models & Super-Resolution**
   - **SRGAN (Super-Resolution GAN)**:
     - **Adversarial Loss**: Fools discriminator to generate perceptually realistic images (not pixel-wise MSE).
     - **Perceptual Loss**: Uses VGG features for texture detail.
   - **LAKDNet**: Dual attention (spatial + channel) for feature aggregation.

#### **6. Advanced Architectures**
   - **Inception Module** (Q9):
     - Parallel convolutions (1×1, 3×3, 5×5) + pooling, concatenated along channels (`dim=1`).
     - Correct implementation:
       ```python
       x1 = self.conv1x1(x)
       x2 = self.conv3x3(x)
       x3 = self.conv5x5(x)
       x4 = self.conv1x1(self.pool(x))  # Pool → 1×1 conv
       out = torch.cat([x1, x2, x3, x4], dim=1)
       ```
   - **ResNet Blocks** (Q19):
     - Skip connections with `1×1` conv for dimension matching:
       ```python
       out += self.shortcut(identity)  # If stride/channel mismatch
       ```
   - **U-Net**:
     - Downsampling: **MaxPool2d** (kernel=2, stride=2).
     - Upsampling: Transpose convolution or interpolation.

#### **7. Loss Functions**
   - **Left-Right Consistency Loss** (Q6):
     \[
     \mathcal{L}_{\text{LR}} = \frac{1}{N} \sum |D_L - \text{warp}(D_R)|,
     \]
     where `warp` uses disparity to reconstruct \(D_L\) from \(D_R\).
   - **Adversarial Loss (SRGAN)**:
     \[
     \mathcal{L}_{\text{adv}} = \log(1 - D(G(z))),
     \]
     where \(D\) is the discriminator and \(G\) is the generator.

#### **8. Memory & Computational Efficiency**
   - **VGGNet** (Q16):
     - **Memory**: Early conv layers (large feature maps).
     - **Parameters**: FC layers (e.g., `4096 × 4096` weights).
   - **1×1 Convolutions**: Reduce channels before expensive ops (e.g., 3×3 conv).

#### **9. Attention Mechanisms**
   - **Dual Attention (LAKDNet)**:
     - **Spatial Attention**: Highlights "where" to focus.
     - **Channel Attention**: Highlights "what" features to emphasize.
   - **Transformer Self-Attention**: Captures global dependencies (not in LAKDNet).

---

### **Key Equations**
| **Concept**               | **Equation**                                                                 |
|---------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Conv Output Shape**     | \( \left\lfloor \frac{W - K + 2P}{S} \right\rfloor + 1 \)                  |
| **IoU**                   | \( \frac{A_{\text{inter}}}{A_{\text{GT}} + A_{\text{Pred}} - A_{\text{inter}}} \) |
| **Precision/Recall**      | \( \text{Precision} = \frac{\text{TP}}{\text{TP} + \text{FP}} \), \( \text{Recall} = \frac{\text{TP}}{\text{TP} + \text{FN}} \) |
| **MAE (Bounding Boxes)**  | \( \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} \frac{1}{4} \sum_{j=1}^{4} |GT_{ij} - P_{ij}| \)       |
| **FC Layer Parameters**   | \( (\text{Input Features}) \times (\text{Output Neurons}) + \text{Biases} \) |
| **Left-Right Loss**       | \( \mathcal{L}_{\text{LR}} = \frac{1}{N} \sum |D_L - \text{warp}(D_R)| \)  |
| **F1-Score**              | \( 2 \times \frac{\text{Precision} \times \text{Recall}}{\text{Precision} + \text{Recall}} \) |

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graph**
```mermaid
graph TD
    %% Core Topics
    DL[Deep Learning] --> CNN[Convolutional Neural Networks]
    DL --> OD[Object Detection]
    DL --> DE[Depth Estimation]
    DL --> GM[Generative Models]
    DL --> AT[Attention Mechanisms]

    %% CNN Subtopics
    CNN --> AR[Architectures: AlexNet, VGG, ResNet, Inception]
    CNN --> CL[Convolutional Layers]
    CNN --> PL[Pooling Layers]
    CNN --> FC[Fully Connected Layers]
    CNN --> TL[Transfer Learning]
    CL --> KS["Kernel Size, Stride, Padding"]
    CL --> OS["Output Shape Calculation"]
    PL --> MP[MaxPool]
    PL --> AP[AvgPool]
    PL --> MinP[MinPool]
    FC --> PC["Parameter Count"]

    %% Object Detection
    OD --> Metrics[Metrics: IoU, Precision, Recall, F1, MAE]
    OD --> Pipelines[Pipelines: Fast R-CNN, Faster R-CNN]
    OD --> RPN[Region Proposal Network]
    Metrics --> IoU["IoU = Intersection / Union"]
    Metrics --> MAE["MAE for Bounding Boxes"]
    Pipelines --> SS[Selective Search]
    Pipelines --> ROI[ROI Pooling]

    %% Depth Estimation
    DE --> Mono[Monocular]
    DE --> Stereo[Stereo]
    Mono --> Challenges["Scale Ambiguity, Textureless Regions"]
    Stereo --> LRCL[Left-Right Consistency Loss]
    LRCL --> Warp["warp(depth_R) → depth_L"]

    %% Generative Models
    GM --> SRGAN[SRGAN]
    SRGAN --> AdvLoss["Adversarial Loss: Fool Discriminator"]
    SRGAN --> PercLoss["Perceptual Loss: VGG Features"]

    %% Attention
    AT --> Dual["Dual Attention (LAKDNet)"]
    Dual --> Spatial["Spatial Attention"]
    Dual --> Channel["Channel Attention"]
    AT --> Transformer["Transformer Self-Attention"]

    %% Relationships
    AR --> TL
    CL --> OS
    OS --> PC
    IoU --> MAE
    LRCL --> Warp
    AdvLoss --> PercLoss
    Dual --> LAKDNet["LAKDNet Architecture"]
```

```mermaid
graph TD
    %% Architectures
    AR[CNN Architectures] --> AlexNet[AlexNet]
    AR --> VGG[VGGNet]
    AR --> ResNet[ResNet]
    AR --> Inception[Inception]
    AR --> UNet[U-Net]

    %% Key Components
    AlexNet --> FC7["FC7 Layer (Modified for Custom Classes)"]
    VGG --> Mem["Memory: Early Conv Layers"]
    VGG --> Params["Parameters: FC Layers"]
    ResNet --> Bottleneck["Bottleneck Blocks (1×1 Conv)"]
    Inception --> Concatenate["Concatenate 1×1, 3×3, 5×5, Pool"]
    UNet --> Downsample["MaxPool2d (kernel=2, stride=2)"]
    UNet --> Upsample["Transpose Conv / Interpolation"]

    %% Loss Functions
    LF[Loss Functions] --> IoULoss[IoU Loss]
    LF --> MAE[MAE for Bounding Boxes]
    LF --> LRCL[Left-Right Consistency Loss]
    LF --> AdvLoss[Adversarial Loss (SRGAN)]
    LRCL --> GridSample["Grid Sample for Warping"]
```

```mermaid
graph TD
    %% Challenges
    Challenges[Challenges in Deep Learning] --> MonoDE[Monocular Depth Estimation]
    Challenges --> OD[Object Detection]
    Challenges --> GM[Generative Models]

    MonoDE --> Scale["Scale Ambiguity"]
    MonoDE --> Textureless["Textureless Regions"]
    OD --> Occlusion["Occlusions"]
    OD --> Discontinuities["Depth Discontinuities"]
    GM --> Perceptual["Perceptual Quality (SRGAN)"]
    GM --> Pixelwise["Pixel-wise vs. Perceptual Loss"]
```

---

### **Exam Preparation Tips**
1. **Focus Areas**:
   - **CNN Math**: Output shapes, parameter counts, 1×1 convolutions.
   - **Object Detection**: IoU, precision/recall, Fast R-CNN vs. Faster R-CNN.
   - **Depth Estimation**: Monocular vs. stereo challenges, left-right consistency.
   - **Code Snippets**: PyTorch implementations (Inception, ResNet blocks, pooling).
   - **Architectures**: VGG (memory/parameters), U-Net (downsampling), SRGAN (adversarial loss).

2. **Practice**:
   - Calculate **output shapes** for conv/pooling layers (Q3, Q5).
   - Compute **IoU/MAE** manually (Q4, Q8).
   - Modify **pretrained models** (Q2, Q11).
   - Implement **custom layers** (MinPool, Inception, ResNet blocks).

3. **Avoid Pitfalls**:
   - **Fast R-CNN** uses **Selective Search** (not RPN).
   - **Left-Right Loss** uses `grid_sample` to warp depth maps (Q6).
   - **1×1 Convolutions** reduce channels **before** expensive ops (Q18).
